key_insight: A generative framework using neural stochastic differential equations learns state-dependent drift and diffusion to accurately model and simulate cell-state dynamics, enabling realistic in silico perturbation studies of development and disease.
problem_solved: Existing models struggle to capture stochastic, state-dependent variability in cellular trajectories and to generate realistic counterfactuals; this work provides a principled continuous-time generative model that addresses both fidelity and perturbation prediction.
method: Model cell dynamics as neural stochastic differential equations (SDEs) where both drift and diffusion are parameterized by neural networks conditioned on state.
Fit the model to single-cell (time-series or snapshot-derived) data to learn state-dependent stochastic rules for transitions.
Use the trained generative SDE to simulate trajectories and perform in silico perturbation experiments to predict developmental or disease responses.
impact: Provides AI/ML practitioners a scalable, probabilistic continuous-time approach for modeling complex stochastic systems, improving generative fidelity and enabling counterfactual/perturbation analyses applicable beyond biology (e.g., finance, physics, engineering).
visual_elements: Schematic of a neural SDE: state -> drift network + diffusion network -> stochastic trajectory sampler
Side-by-side trajectory plots: ground-truth single-cell trajectories vs. model-generated trajectories and baselines
Perturbation diagram: how targeted changes shift predicted developmental/disease trajectories (before/after)
Pipeline flowchart: data input → neural SDE training → simulation & perturbation → validation metrics
paper_title: Learning cell dynamics with neural differential equations
paper_authors: Michael E. Vinyard, Anders W. Rasmussen, Ruitong Li, Allon M. Klein, Gad Getz
